Mechanistically, the reaction between O 3/NO 2 and tyrosine involves the formation of long-lived reactive oxygen intermediates (ROI), likely via hydrogen abstraction from the phenolic OH group, yielding tyrosyl radicals (phenoxy radical derivatives of tyrosine) that can further react with NO 2 to form nitrotyrosine residues as shown in Figure 4 .
329, 362, 363 The two-step protein nitration by air pollutants is similar to the endogenous nitration of proteins by peroxynitrite (ONOO –)
298, 328, 364 formed from nitrous oxide (NO) and superoxide anions (O 2 –).
301, 365, 366 For endogeneous protein nitration by ONOO –, both radical and electron transfer reaction pathways have been proposed.
367 Besides nitration, tyrosyl radicals can also undergo hydroxylation or self-reaction (cross-linking) to form dityrosine derivatives ( Figure 4 ).
